Following our call to reduce defensive hedges last week, we addfurther to Valueby tactically raising Banks to OW at the expense of Healthcare. Banks arenot oversold anymore,and still face many headwinds, but theyde-rated sharply ytd, aredeeply unloved and offer cheap optionality on reducing macro risks. Brexit isa wild card, but yesterday’s vote suggests that a deal is a more probable outcome than a no-deal.Banks offer cheap optionality on improving macro.The sectorrebounded recently, mainlydue to short-covering,but remainsthe worst performerytd in Europe. Banks areconsensus UW, aredeeply unloved and theirprice relative to the overall market is nearthe lowest level on record. Valuations have been lookingcheap for a while but Banks are now trading at the biggest P/E and P/B discounts to the market in historyfollowing the ytd de-rating. While banks’profitability still faces many structural headwinds, sector sentiment is depressed butcould benefit from improving macro: 1) Euro and UKPMIsarethe lowest in six years but might be close toaninflection point,as Chinese activity is improving, trade tensions are easing and money supply is rebounding; 2) Bond yields could continue to stabilise,as further aggressiveFed/ECB/BoEmonetary easing is not guaranteed, talk offiscal expansion is growingand bond positioning is still crowded.

BE11:16am

Brexit is awild card but no-deal risk hasreceded.Arguably, Brexit remainsa key drag onBanks sentiment, not only in the UK but across theEurozone too. While uncertainty is not going away, yesterday’sapproval in principal of the PM’s deal by Parliament reduces further the chances of adisruptive no-deal outcome, in our view. We would use any Brexit-related market weaknessas an opportunity to add to Banks and domestic plays.Value rotationis tracking.MSCI Europe Value has outperformed Growth by 5% since early Septemberandwe believe there is more to go. Most investors have lagged their benchmark during the recent risk-on and might be tempted to reduce their extreme Value under-exposure into year-end,as the valuation gap with Growth and Quality is still near extreme whilemacro tail-risksare abating. We fund our Banks upgrade by cutting Healthcare from OW to MW. The sector is the best performerin the past six monthsand might be hurt by political uncertainty ahead of the US electionin 2020.

Notwithstanding that victory, the Prime Minister’s programme motion was defeated by 308 to 322. In effect, this defeat now makes it very difficult for all stages of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill to pass through the House of Commons and the House of Lords with appropriate scrutiny in time for the UK to leave the EU by 31 October. The entirety of the parliamentary Conservative Party (257 MPs) voted in favour of both the Withdrawal Agreement Bill and the programme motion, but while 18 pro-deal Labour MPs voted for the Bill, only 5 of those Labour MPs voted in favour of the Prime Minister’s programme motion. All in all, a group of around 20 Opposition MPs who voted for the deal but also voted for more scrutiny of the deal will prove to be the fulcrum of the next parliamentary stage of the Brexit endgame.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

It now falls to PM Johnson to set out his response to this evening’s events. In a brief statement in the House of Commons, the Prime Minister asserted that “one way or another, we will leave the EU with this deal.” In our view, the European Council will withhold judgement on the Prime Minister’s pending request for an Article 50 extension until the purpose of that extension becomes clearer in Westminster. After Tuesday evening’s votes, President Tusk stated that in order “to avoid a no-deal Brexit” he would “recommend that the EU-27 accept the UK request for an extension.”

BE11:21am

We continue to think there is insufficient appetite in the House of Commons for a pre-Brexit general election — either via the two-thirds majority required under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act, or via the simple majority required for an amendable one-line bill. We also maintain the view that any move by Labour backbenchers to attach a confirmatory second referendum to the Withdrawal Agreement Bill is unlikely to command a parliamentary majority. As such, we expect PM Johnson to return to the House of Commons in the coming days with a new programme motion that essentially allows more time for line-by-line scrutiny of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill in each of its remaining parliamentary stages. Shortly after the PM’s defeat on the programme motion, the Leader of the Opposition urged the Prime Minister to “work with us [the Labour frontbench] to agree a reasonable timetable” for ratification.

GBKrona @BE - Varadkar & Euro Parliament have just said they will back an extension to Jan 31st - so all Brexit options back on the table now...
BE11:21am

Good lord, there's a lot of this. Where are the probabilities?

11:21 am
BE11:22am

5. On its journey through both chambers, we expect several amendments to the Withdrawal Agreement Bill, including one that seeks to establish a customs union as a key negotiating objective for the UK’s future relationship with the EU. Other amendments seeking closer UK-EU alignment on workers’ rights and a role for Parliament in the potential extension of the transition period beyond end-2020 are also likely to be forthcoming. Whether or not the Prime Minister accommodates these concerns — mostly in an effort to win over wavering, pro-deal Labour MPs — it is worth emphasising that any commitment on the future relationship can effectively be overturned by the next government with a majority in the next Parliament. As for PM Johnson’s ability to deliver Brexit with a deal, we remain sceptical that any of these amendments will jeopardise the safe passage of the legally binding Withdrawal Agreement negotiated and signed off in Brussels.
6. On terminal outcomes, we leave our probabilities unchanged: 70% on a Brexit deal, 5% on a “no deal” Brexit and 25% on no Brexit at all. On our new baseline path, we now expect the EU to offer a flexible three-month extension, for the purposes of facilitating a more protracted period of parliamentary ratification. Although, in theory, that technical extension is likely to expire on 31 January 2020, in practice we expect it to fall once the Withdrawal Agreement Bill receives royal assent — most likely in mid- to late November.

BE11:22am

Phew. There we go. Lovely, comforting prercentages. They make everything better.

 Fresnillo – Silver production was 7% below consensus, driven by weaker
grades (9% below Macquarie estimates) with consistency to the geological
model still an issue. However we are encouraged to see a sequential increase
in volumes (in line with our forecasts), with the improvement in development
metres shown in Q2-19 maintained. Additionally gold production of 15.6koz
was 27% higher than consensus. Fresnillo maintained FY19 grade guidance
and is now guiding to higher grades and volumes in Q4-19 (previously 2020).
 Saucito – Silver production was 8% below consensus with higher volumes
offset by lower grades. Gold production was 14% above consensus.
 Juanicipio – earthworks have started on the plant, however previous start-up
guidance (H2-20) was not reiterated. We highlighted the potential for the start
date to be delayed to H1-21 in our site visit feedback note
 Herradura – gold production missed expectations due to the lower grades as
a results of the lower availability of the DLP; with the 13th leachpad starting this
quarter, gold recovery is expected to improve in Q4-19.

BE11:39am

Our view: Solid performance from Antofagasta in Q3 with copper production in line, but much better gold production and strong cost control bode well for 2019
consensus expectations. Better performance at Centinela gold grades drove the gold beat but this should fade with Centinela copper grades next year. Cost
control is a positive – even after accounting for the currency tailwinds, we get a 4% improvement over our forecasts. The company now expects year-end costs
to be below $1.25/lb and a lower CLP in Q4 will also help. 2020 production guidance is at 725kt-755kt, which is 2% ahead of our 724kt forecast.
The situation in Chile remains fluid, however President Sebastian Pinera has overnight provided new tax reforms, a guaranteed minimum income and health
insurance, which could help stem the current disruptions. ANTO has guided to 5,000t of potential impact in Q4 but this is also a fluid expectation as the unrest
has yet to significantly impact the operations.
In a lower copper price environment, every cent ANTO is able to squeeze out of the cost base is a positive, especially as they go through a relatively light year
production-wise next year and see capex rising. The underlying environment for copper also remains a question heading into 2020. We continue to view
Antofagasta as a preferred copper exposure and shares hold a 13% total return on our 12-month forecasts supporting our Sector Perform rating.

BE11:39am

That's RBC

BE11:40am

Q3 copper production came in 3% below MSe while shipments missed by 7% possibly on timing. By-product output surprised positively, leading to 6% lower net cash costs. Overall we see ~1% downside to our 2019 EBITDA forecast. FY2020 copper guidance was provided at 725-755kt vs our estimate of 752kt. Copper production miss small, Gold and Molybdenum output beat. Group copper production incl. att Zaldivar for the quarter came in at 197kt, 3% below MSe of 204kt. The small misses vs our estimates were across all mines (see 2) and indicate a slowdown in the final month of the quarter vs the previous reported COCHILCO numbers. Gold production was robust during the period (+21% vs MSe) on account of higher grades at Centinela mine, which suggests some upside risks to company guidance for FY19. Sales volumes of copper and molybdenum came in at 197kt (7% below MSe) and 3.1kt (30% above MSe), respectively, and gold sales were 28% ahead of MSe. Lastly, provisional pricing came in at US$51mn which is broadly in-line with our forecasts. In summary, the above factors would constitute a modest (immaterial) downside risk to our FY19 EBITDA forecast in the tune of ~1%.FY2020 copper production guidance ~2% below MSe at the midpoint: The company is guiding for a copper output range of 725-755kt for 2020, which is slightly below our forecast of 752kt at the midpoint. We note that several tailwinds appear to mitigate the impact of lower production on cash costs, notably favourable CLP/USD rates and lower Copper TC/RCs. We anticipate cash cost guidance to be provided during Q1 2020. As for 2019, the company has retained its volume guidance but indicate a possible 5kt as a result of the ongoing unrest and strikes in the country (and at Antucoya). We did not factor this risk in our forecasts.At the mine level, (1) Los Pelambres: Copper output was -1% below and sales volumes were lower by -9% due to timing of shipments. Moly output was robust at 17% above our forecast. (2) Centinela: Copper output was -5% below MSe due to lower grades; however, this was partly offset by higher gold output (+21% vs MSe). (3) Antucoya & Zaldivar have both missed our forecasts by 4% and 7%, respectively.Net cash cost performance positively surprised on higher by-product credits. Gross cash costs incl. att Zaldivar came in at US$1.60/lb, exactly in-line with our forecast. Net cash costs positively surprised, coming in at US$1.12, -6% below our forecast of US$1.19/lb on account of higher by-product credits. Realized prices slightly lower: Q3 provisional pricing adjustment for copper is reported at US$-51.4mn (vs MSe US$-52.6mn), implying realized Cu prices of US$2.51/lb vs MSe at US$2.52/lb. Reasonable valuation, prefer Lundin Mining among copper producers. Valuation is reasonable with shares pricing in a LT Cu price of US$2.57/lb vs our LT forecast of US$3.18/lb; nonetheless, the company has limited levers to pull to change earnings power or capital structure. (1) Cost cutting gains are likely to offset inflation, falling grades, and rising rock hardness. (2) projects should deliver a modest 2% 2018-20e volume CAGR; accelerating growth and/or opting for external M&A could face B/S and permitting constraints.

We initiate on M&G Plc with an OW rating and Dec-20 271p SoTP based
price target. The key attraction at M&G Plc, in our view, is its cash flow
profile from asset management, with-profits and annuities businesses. We
note that, on top of earnings, we expect M&G Plc to release capital
backing the annuities business, which is in run off. This provides a strong
cushion to the dividend. Based on management’s guidance on capital
generation, we calculate the dividend has 1.5x cover, which we see as
reasonable and the remaining cash could be used to make bolt-on
acquisitions or lower debt over time. In our view it’s a bit early to give
credit for growth prospects coming from PruFunds and third party asset
management, but we see it as a free option with the stock. M&G shares are
trading at 8.3x 2021e PE and offer a yield of 8.3% 2020e.

BE11:49am

17% yield over the next 18 months, and scope for improved rating. Our initial view of M&G ahead of its demerger was that its investment case was unproven (see 'Dissecting M&G') - with not much growth and too much debt. However, while the business outlook might be unexciting, the share price offers surprisingly compelling value. Specifically, after two days of significant flow-back post the demerger, the shares now carry a final 2019 dividend yield of 7.8% plus a further 9.1% in 2020e. Implicitly, investors will receive almost 17% in dividends alone over the next 18 months, which should also be supplemented by some re-rating as the short-term flow-back starts to ease. For instance, if the yield were merely to match that of its closest peer- it would imply a further 18% upside, giving a realistic 35% total return over the period. Mainly on valuation grounds, we thus initiate on the shares with a Buy.

BE11:50am

We initiate coverage of M&G with an Overweight rating; our price target of 256p implies 26% potential upside and 35% potential total shareholder return based on our current dividend yield estimate. However, we argue the stock deserves a FY20E dividend yield of 7% (our PT implies 7.2% and a FY20E PE of 10.5x – see full assumptions on the following page) akin to a closed book life insurer or an asset manager in outflows, versus a compelling market-implied dividend yield of 9.1% on our FY20 DPS estimate of GBp18.5 following its first two days of trading. While the path to this rerating may be choppy as we expect pretty much a full recycling in M&G's shareholder base (away from that of Prudential's), we believe the stock should screen well with income investors, which should over time replace the growth-biased investors interested in the Pru Asia story.

The catalyst is here. We reiterate our OW rating and Top Pick status for Prudential with a revised PT of GBp1,696 post de-merger, implying 21% potential upside. We have historically been strong proponents of Prudential as the only true large-cap growth stock in the sector. We believe the demerged Pru plc offers a cleaner and clearer investment case and more Asian exposure, driving our operating profit CAGR estimate of 12%. With substantially above-average growth at knock-down multiples versus history of 10.4x 2020E P/E and c0.8x P/EV, we think Prudential should be firmly on the radar of investors looking for growth.

BE11:55am

Downgrading to Hold on valuation grounds. Following the demerger of its UK and European operations this week, Prudential plc now consists solely of the Asian and US operations. Our new forecasts purely reflect the new shape of the group and are in practice unchanged from our previous Asian and US numbers, as is our underlying target price of 1450p. Though we see the potential for attractive long-term growth in the group's Asian business, we estimate the continuing group has effectively re-rated by 15% in the two days since the demerger. With upside of just 3% to our price target, we downgrade our recommendation to Hold.

BE12:11pm

Whilst we appreciate that the Prosus bid offers significant upside to the Takeaway.com bid and yesterday's closing share price, we expect further bids to emerge, either in the form of an improved counteroffer from Takeaway.com or an improved bid from Prosus if the bid is not accepted by shareholders:

-The market is pricing in a further bid: Just Eat shares are currently trading at £7.35/sh, a 3.5% premium the the proposed Prosus bid, indicating that the market is expecting an improved counter offer.

-Shareholders disapproved of the bid at higher levels: In early September, Eminance capital, a 4.4% beneficial owner in Just Eat published a strongly worded statement suggesting the agreed 0.09774 Takeaway.com/Just Eat shares undervalued the company, joining Aberdeen Standard in its view. Notably, when the letter was published Takeaway.com shares were trading at higher levels, valuing the bid at 770-780p/sh.

-Bid seems light on comparable multiples: Takeaway.com purchased Delivery Hero’s German assets for €930m, valuing the business on an 8.7x FY18 sales multiple, which for context would value Just Eat at c. £12/sh. While we do not expect Just Eat to command as high a sales multiple given its more mature stage in development, we do believe that 710p/sh bid from Prosus is light.
